Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2008 05:30PM soccermom96 wrote: I had extensive DCIS in right breast and was totally convinced that the tender spot in my armpit for several weeks before surgery was some kind of metastatic growth.  I did not have US but an MRI with no signs of invasion.  My SNB was totally clear at surgery.  Someone said that all the testing(dye injections etc) kind of stirs things up.  As Beesie would remind us(and did in some other post I cannot find), DCIS does not go lymph nodes.
Posts.Title: worries about tenderness under arm... RhondaM sarahzxe

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2008 03:50PM soccermom96 wrote: Rayhope---I feel pretty good, but to be honest, I think I turned some sort of corner yesterday.  Until then, I'd been pretty lazy and unfocused...kind of wandering around and leaving everything I started half done and taking lots of naps....and I've been off the drugs for quite a while!  Somehow I woke up yesterday with lots of energy and ready to go...like my old self.  I started PT last week and that has helped with the expander pain, though I still have Iron Bra syndrome.  I did have an allergic reaction to the post surgery bra and got some blisters where the band was.  I stole my teenages son's T shirts (really soft) and mostly wear those under my clothes.  I'm glad it's winter and I can hide in sweatshirts.
Posts.Title: Most comfortable bra for expanders? rayhope soccermom96

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2008 06:11PM soccermom96 wrote: Rayhope---I don't know if you get over Iron Bra as long as you have expanders.  And I've found that going out in the cold makes it worse.  That was a surprise.  Anyhow, I didn't ask for PT, the PS suggested and I went along.  Not like I had anything else to do, you know?  When I went for 3 week follow up, he suggested.  I was 4 weeks postop when I went so I'd wait til you get clearance before trying any of this.  Lay on floor, extend arm over head and drop it toward floor, pushing on your elbow with your other hand.  Count to 8.  Repeat, starting with 5 reps twice a day and adding one a day til you are up to 10 reps.  I can lay the whole back of my hand on the floor now, had to work up to it, one knuckle at a time and my armpits burned!  Next stand in front of a mirror and hold your fists in front of your chest, knuckles facing and do isometric pushes.  Then lock your fingers and pull apart (but your not really pulling apart because your fingers are locked, know what I mean?)  Finally, same position.  One fist on top of the other and push down, while pushing up with bottom fist.  Switch hands halfway thru.  It's important to stand up straight when you do the standing stuff.  Shoulders back, stomach in. The PT explained that since the chest muscles are being stretched, the muscles in the back need to be strengthened so you stand straight and don't get all hunched over.  I also read somewhere that we tend to sort of hunch to protect the area that hurts anyway, so it's important to work on posture.
Posts.Title: Most comfortable bra for expanders? rayhope soccermom96

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2008 02:40PM soccermom96 wrote: I'm almost 5 weeks out from same surgery and my PS says no bra yet.  And then they will give very specific instructions.  You might want to check with surgeon.  I go for my first fill tomorrow!
Posts.Title: Most comfortable bra for expanders? rayhope soccermom96

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2008 07:52AM soccermom96 wrote: evry surgeon is different tho most seem to add something to keep the expander in place.  I started with 150cc and waking up with "something" was better than nothing.  It might be based somewhat on size...I'm 5 ft 7 so not a little tiny thing.

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2009 04:29PM soccermom96 wrote: Janet----I am so sorry that you are having to go through this.  I am certain it was not an easy decision (it never is!) and then to have the government dictate your healthcare!  I'd be furious too.  I'm sorry.
Posts.Title: I am soooooooo ANGRY!!!!! auroravtj mikita5

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2009 10:12PM soccermom96 wrote: LJ13---I'm sorry but I disagree.  The cost of a 2nd mastectomy is less than chemo, radiation and possible surgery should there be a recurrence.  Since Aurorajtv has DCIS, tamoxifen is probably indicated.  What's the cost of the drug for 5 years versus that prophy mx that then eliminates the need for tamoxifen?  In a person with kidney damage?  While I agree that the whole medical complex needs rethinking, this decision is shortsighted.  There are some very expensive procedures being done in this country that are simply not done outside the US....for example, organ transplants in the medically compromised.  Aurorajtv---sorry to talk about you in the third person!  Good luck in the fight.
Posts.Title: I am soooooooo ANGRY!!!!! auroravtj mikita5

Posts.Title: PinkyLee Traci-----TripNeg soccermom96

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2009 03:16PM soccermom96 wrote: Liz---No question is idiotic!!!  With some creativity you can tackle the laundry issue.  Lisa is probably right...you can put it in the washer.  It's the transfer to the dryer or hanger that is tough.  You can fold dry stuff.  Please don't rush to do too much.  This is major surgery and you will need time to heal.  If I overdid it, I had to rest a lot the next day.   So be patient and take advantage of the healing time.  Good time to curl up and watch movies with your girls.  Every surgeon seems to have different thoughts on what you can/cannot do.  I am 7 weeks post op and my PS still won't let me do Pilates.  I got a flat out "no" at my second fill yesterday.  I can walk and do stretching exercises as much as I want, but still no heavy lifting.   Haven't had one complication, so I'm grateful and follow his orders.  You will be fine.  As women, we all find a way to get things done, simply because they have to be done.  Hugs to you.  Lisa
Posts.Title: Hello from a NEW member! elizzim elizzim

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2009 06:27PM soccermom96 wrote: Liz---Thinking of you tonite as you prepare for tomorrow.  I reached a point where I wanted to be done waiting and just wanted the surgery over.  I hope you have a peaceful nite.  Hugs.
Posts.Title: Hello from a NEW member! elizzim elizzim

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2008 04:19PM soccermom96 wrote: Could not figure out how to do write as PM and hope I'm not breaking the rules.  The Abramson Cancer Center at Hospital of University of Pennsylvania is very good.  Their team approach does include residents, as any teaching hospital will, but the docs are very good, including the radiation oncologist.  Brian Czarnecki is good surgeon there.  Dahlia Sataloff at Pennsylvania Hospital is one of top breast surgeons in Philadelphia.  Gordon Schwartz is at Jefferson University in Philadelphia. Older, very good.  I don't know so much about Baltimore.
Posts.Title: Doctor in Philadelphia/Baltimore area EleanorJ maryanne56

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2009 09:36AM soccermom96 wrote: Liz---Sorry but it's likely laundry will be off limits for a couple of weeks.  You will be limited in what you can lift so even if you aren't a touch off balance from the drugs, wet towels weigh more than 3 lbs.  Wet jeans are very heavy.  I was able to fold dry clothes and maybe the arm movement was a kind of therapy.  You certainly can't carry the baskets.  Showering seems to be surgeon dependent.  I was allowed to shower in the hospital (if I had wanted to).  I waited til I got home. Others had more restrictions.
Posts.Title: Hello from a NEW member! elizzim elizzim

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2009 03:04PM soccermom96 wrote: Elizzem---I had the very same procedure on 11/12.  Like you, my mother died of BC and I knew I would one day be diagnosed.  I'm 47 and have 2 sons, 12 and 15.  I was in pretty good shape before the surgery..walked 2 miles a day, Pilates classes once or twice a week.  I went into the hospital very early on a Wed morning (needed to make arrangements to get kids to school) and came home late morning Friday.  I was walking under my own power and could take care of myself in terms of getting dressed (slowly but I could), feeding myself, showering, bathroom duties (as in I could wipe myself--just in case you were wondering as I was).  It was maybe a week before I dried my own hair.  I slept in a recliner with 2-3 pillows for maybe two weeks;  I could get in and out of it myself.  Drains (you will have at least 2) were a pain but not painful. No driving for a bit...this seems to vary a lot but it sounds like you have people lined up to chauffer your girls. I was a little dopey but functional.  Could I have made myself a lite lunch ?  Absolutely.  But you can't reach so make sure everything is low.  I took myself off the narcotics before the two week mark...too many side effects.  I was limited to lifting no more than 3 lbs.  That's not much.  You cannot do laundry.  My husband (bless him) did a lot.  I ordered groceries online and had them delivered.  The guy brought them in the house for me, I put them away.  A long list of friends cooked dinners.   What am I missing?  I did not need chemo or rads so won't be any help there.  I will say a prayer for you on Tuesday.  It will be OK...while I was dreading the surgery.  It was far easier than I imagined.
Posts.Title: Hello from a NEW member! elizzim elizzim

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2008 03:48PM soccermom96 wrote: Tomorrow will be 7 weeks since BM w/TE and I still have days when I'm dragging and need to relax for a bit.  I know at 2 weeks I was functioning but barely.  I checked the November thread often as I recovered and most of us seemed to be finding new issues to deal with daily.  Two steps forward one back.  As Lasrnw wrote, we do too much and then have to back off.  Dealing with expanders takes a toll, expanders in the cold weather was new to us, as was sneezing and coughing.  Be kind to yourself, nap as needed, eat well.  Getting the drains out will be a plus for you.  This is major surgery and even metabolizing the anesthetics from surgery takes a few days.  I have to go back to work on Monday and already know I will need some work from home days for a bit.  Listen to your body and don't compare yourself to the Superwomen!
Posts.Title: Frustrated With Recovery flb1011 2Hands4me
